title: Quincy chef to compete on ‘Top Chef’ Season 23
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Laurence Louie, owner of Rubato cafe in Quincy, will compete on 'Top Chef' Season 23 in the Carolinas.
Season 23 airs March 9 at 9 p.m. ET on Bravo, with Kristin Kish, Tom Colicchio, and Gail Simmons as judges.
Rubato, opened in 2022, replaces Louie's mother's Contempo Bakery; Louie is a past 'Chopped' champion and James Beard semifinalist.

title: Zipcar to close Seaport headquarters, cut more than 100 jobs
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Zipcar will close its Seaport headquarters, resulting in over 100 layoffs as operations consolidate in New Jersey.
Avis Budget Group states the Boston car-sharing services will remain operational despite headquarters closure.
The consolidation impacts 126 employees, including 65 in Boston and 61 remote workers, with layoffs by April 1.

title: Robert Kraft explained the ‘different factors’ that led to Mike Vrabel’s hiring
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Robert Kraft hired Mike Vrabel as Patriots head coach shortly after firing Jerod Mayo following a 4-13 season.
Kraft cited his instinct and Vrabel's player and coaching experience, including with the Titans, as reasons for the hire.
Vrabel's leadership led the Patriots to the Super Bowl LX against the Seahawks in his first season as head coach.

title: 23-year-old woman fatally struck after car breaks down on Route 18 in New Bedford
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Ruby Quiro Santos, 23, died after being struck on Route 18 in New Bedford following her car breaking down.
The accident involved a 2018 Honda Accord, which hit Santos and another woman, the Audi assisting her, and a police vehicle.
Massachusetts State Police are investigating the crash; the other woman hit remains critical but stable, others have minor injuries.

title: 5 restaurants we can’t wait to try in February
author: Jillian Dara
bullets: Ama at The Atlas in Allston offers global comfort cuisine with Nepali influences, emphasizing sustainable, zero-waste dishes.
Boxfish Restaurant in Watertown features an ocean-to-table concept with a focus on seafood, including brown butter lobster toast.
Swingers in Back Bay combines indoor mini golf with dining options like Detroit-style pizza and gourmet street food.

title: Panera to close bakery facility in Franklin, lay off nearly 100 workers
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Panera to shut down Franklin bakery, laying off 92 employees as it shifts to a par-baked goods model.
The Franklin facility at 290 Beaver St. will cease operations by the end of March, according to Panera.
Panera offers severance and job assistance to affected employees as part of its 'Panera Rise' strategy.

title: 16-year-old New Zealander ran a 3:48 mile at BU’s Terrier Classic, set a junior world record
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Sam Ruthe, 16, set a junior world record with a 3:48.88 mile at BU's Terrier Classic.
Ruthe broke New Zealand's national mile record previously held by Olympic gold medalist John Walker since 1982.
Ruthe is recognized as the youngest to break a four-minute mile, achieving this feat at age 15.

title: Watch: Ms. G, Massachusetts’ official groundhog, issues annual prediction
author: Heather Alterisio
bullets: Ms. G, Massachusetts' official groundhog, predicted six more weeks of winter at Drumlin Farm in Lincoln.
Around 50 people braved 16-degree weather to watch Ms. G make her annual prediction at Mass Audubon's sanctuary.
Designated in 2014, Ms. G has a 60% prediction accuracy and serves as a wildlife ambassador for the state.

title: Massachusetts keeps losing residents to other states, Census finds
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Massachusetts experienced a net loss of over 30,000 residents to other states last year, with Florida and New Hampshire leading.
Census Bureau data shows Massachusetts ranked fifth nationally for out-migration, primarily due to high costs and taxes.
State's slight population growth attributed to international immigration, despite a slowing pace due to policy changes.

title: Photos: Day 2 at Something in the Way fest at Roadrunner
author: Boston.com Staff
bullets: Twelve bands performed on Day 2 of the Something in the Way festival at Roadrunner in Brighton.
Seattle's Sunny Day Real Estate headlined the second day of the indie music festival.
Photography by Ben Stas captured performances from Glixen, Wicca Phase Springs Eternal, and more.
